blocks.preview: - Introduction
- Case
- Transitions in Parenteral Nutrition (PN)
- Hospital discharge and home PN
- Adult transition in long-term PN
- Weaning off PN
- Cases review
- Children on long-term PN undergo many transitions, starting from the transition to their home from
- Patients on PN face unique challenges during these transitions
A 3-month-old baby born with intestinal atresia, underwent bowel resection her first week of life. S
You meet with her parents to discuss her care. The parents ask when they will be able to take their
A) PN should be cycled
B) The child should have a tunneled venous catheter placed
C) When the child is weaned off PN
D) When two caregivers are trained in central line care and able to administer PN at home
The parent of a 5-year-old patient with a history intestinal failure due to short bowel syndrome rea
A. Immediately have the parent bring the child to the emergency room for evaluation
B. Inquire how many hours of PN the child typically receives
C. Ask the parent to reposition the patient and try to flush the line again
D. Instruct the parent to call back in the morning to troubleshoot the issue
A 3-year-old boy has received PN since birth due to a history of volvulus. He currently eats orally
All the following are true regarding the transition off PN except,
A. Oral rehydration solutions are beneficial in weaning off PN
B. Continuous tube feeding is necessary to stop PN
C. They should encourage small meals and frequent snacks throughout the day.
D. He will likely need more enteral calories as compared to parenteral calories to maintain his grow

Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheter Recommendations
Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheter Recommendations
blocks.preview: - Smallest diameter + least number of lumens + silicone + upper extremity

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheter Recommendations
blocks.preview: - Most children with intestinal failure require only a single-lumen catheter

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheter Recommendations
blocks.preview: - Larger diameter catheters can cause venous obstruction and thrombosis

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheter Recommendations
blocks.preview: - Multiple lumens are associated with infection, thrombosis and malfunction

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheter Recommendations
blocks.preview: - Silicone catheters permit the use of ethanol locks

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheter Recommendations
blocks.preview: - Subclavian or internal jugular vein access is typically preferred

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheter Recommendations
blocks.preview: - Femoral vein access has a higher risk of infection from stool output

blocks.section: **Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheters**
blocks.preview: - Used for short-term access (<6 months)

blocks.section: **Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheters**
blocks.preview: - Increased risk of peripheral clots, venous stenosis, line breakage, site infection/phlebitis

blocks.section: **Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheters**
blocks.preview: - Decreased infection risk, ability to be de-accessed, good for intermittent access needs

blocks.section: **Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheters**
blocks.preview: - Requires a needlestick to access

blocks.section: **Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Central Venous Catheters**
blocks.preview: - Less stable when accessed, not useful if access needed daily

Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Cycling refers to the administration of PN for < 24 hours, e.g., 8 - 22 hours, commonly 10 - 12 ho

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Pre-requisites to cycling PN

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Stable PN regimen

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Ability to handle larger volume of fluid and nutrients over a shorter amount of time

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Smaller infants and patients with no enteral intake may be less tolerant of cycling PN due to meta

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Benefits of cycling PN

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Decrease intestinal failure associated liver disease

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Allows a more normal daytime routine

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN
blocks.preview: - Increase mobility of the patient when off PN

blocks.preview: - Tapering up/down

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - To avoid hypoglycemia associated with abruptly stopping PN wean rate for the first and last hours

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - Many home PN pumps can be programed to taper up/down automatically

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - Blood sugar monitoring

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - Check serum glucose 30 - 45 minutes after stopping PN with every change in the length of cycle

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Cycling PN - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - Monitor for hyperglycemia and/or glucosuria when receiving PN

blocks.preview: - The caregiver's meticulous care of the Central Venous Catheter (CVC) directly impacts complication

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Recommend at least 2 caregivers are trained

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Training starts in the hospital and continues after discharge

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Ideally caregiver training includes hands on care, rooming in with the child while in the hospital

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Expectations must be clearly outlined for caregivers to optimize safety

blocks.preview: - CVC care

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Proper hand hygiene with any manipulation of the site, tubing, catheter or connections

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Daily examination of the CVC dressing that it is in place, intact, and without signs of infection

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Sterile technique with sterile gloves for dressing changes

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - CVC dressings should be changed every 7 days or if the dressing is not occlusive or compromised

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Skin preparation with antiseptic solution, often chlorhexidine-gluconate (CHG) solution or povidon

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - CHG impregnated supplies (disk, sponge, or dressing) are recommended

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Antiseptic barrier caps should be placed when the catheter is not accessed

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - When accessing the catheter, use a thorough cleansing technique with antiseptic solution ("scrub t

blocks.section: Hospital Discharge and Home PN: Caregiver Training
blocks.preview: - Tubing sets should be changed at least every 24 hours for patients receiving lipids or every 3-4 d

blocks.preview: - Flushing the line before and following PN or medication administration prevents mixing of incompat

blocks.preview: - Mechanical issues (breaks and occlusions)
- Repair is highly successful with minimal infectious risk
- Precipitate, CVC malposition, thrombosis (intracatheter vs catheter associated)
- Work with pharmacist to evaluate potential sources of precipitate
- Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) can successfully clear intracatheter thrombus
- Therapeutic anticoagulation may be required if catheter-related thrombus is identified
McNiven C, *et al. J Pediatr Surg.* 2016; 51:395-7.
Chan AP, *et al. J Pediatr Surg.* 2019;54:517-20.
Wendel D, *et al. J Pediatr Gastroenterol Nutr.* 2021;72:474-86.
- Central Line-associated blood stream infection (CLABSI)
- High risk in intestinal failure
- Immediate evaluation required for fever and initiate treatment with broadspectrum antibiotics
- Reduced with CVC care bundles and antimicrobial locks
- Antimicrobial locks
- Antibiotic
- Specific for spectrum of activity, contributes to resistance
- Other locks (e.g., ethanol, sodium bicarbonate, tetrasodium EDTA, Taurolidine, etc.)
- Broad spectrum, antiseptic
- May also have anticoagulant and/or anti-biofilm activity

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC
Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC
blocks.preview: - CVC tip should be at the cavoatrial junction

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC
blocks.preview: - Consider monitoring with chest radiograph every 6 - 12 months

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC
blocks.preview: - Knowledge of central venous patency is important

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC
blocks.preview: - Ultrasonography is often used but may not be sensitive enough for diagnosis of vascular occlusion

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC
blocks.preview: - CT or MR venography provide more accurate information obstruction however radiation exposure and n

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC
blocks.preview: - Venography is the diagnostic standard however it is invasive, requires radiation, intravenous cont

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC
blocks.preview: - Echocardiogram can visualize thrombi at the tip of the catheter

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Surveillance of the CVC

blocks.preview: - Participation in sports is an important physical and emotional component of childhood

blocks.preview: - If engaging in sports, patients should guard medical devices. A tight-fitting shirt or wrap can ke

blocks.preview: - Recommend avoiding contact sports

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Sports Participation
blocks.preview: - Caregivers should assess the dressing before and after sports as the occlusiveness may be affected

blocks.section: Home PN Additional Considerations: Sports Participation
blocks.preview: - Consider fluid replacement if excessive fluid losses or heat

blocks.preview: - Swimming poses a risk to those with a CVC
- All bodies of water including chlorine treated pools, stagnant (lakes and ponds) and flowing (ocea
- Dry suits for patients with CVC are available but at a high cost and benefit has not been well stu
- A general paucity of data exists and recommendations from intestinal rehabilitation programs vary

blocks.preview: - Transition off, of PN to EN, should be done as soon as possible to shorten PN dependency and the r
- Enteral feeding enhances intestinal adaptation
- Enteral feeds should be started as soon as possible
- Feeds typically start with trophic amounts (< 20\% of goal calories and volume)
- Feeds may be oral or by tube
- If stool/stoma output < 30 - $50 \mathrm{ml} / \mathrm{kg} /$ day, enteral feeds can be advanced
- PN volume can be weaned as enteral feeds are tolerated, depending on a patient's absorptive abilit
- The goal fluid volume for feeds may not meet the caloric intake goals.
- Concentrating feeds may help to achieve goal caloric intake however doing so may lead to higher st
- Enteral fluid and caloric needs are generally higher than caloric goals in PN depending on absorpt

blocks.section: Example Initial Feeding Protocol for Infants with Short Bowel Syndrome

blocks.preview: (low gastric output, minimal abdominal distention, stooling)
- Start continuous feeds $1 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{hr}$ or $10 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{kg} /$ day
- Breast milk first choice
- Donor breast milk if <32 weeks gestational age
- Elemental formula for intolerance
- $1 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{hr} /$ day or $10 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{kg} /$ day
- Based on fluid volume and weight gain
- If feeds tolerated $1 \mathrm{x} / \mathrm{wk}$ and baby is ready, begin 1-2 oral feeds/day (hold
- Stool output $<30-50 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{kg} /$ day or $<6-10$ stools/day
- Continue to increase feeds every 1-3 days
- Stool output $>30-50 \mathrm{~mL} / \mathrm{kg} /$ day or $>6-10$ stools/day
- Hold or reduce feeds
- If stool volume remains high, consider changing the type of feed

blocks.preview: - Mode of feed; oral, nasogastric tube, gastric tube, or gastrojejunostomy tube

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Factors to Consider
blocks.preview: - Early oral feeding is recommended to avoid oral aversion

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Factors to Consider
blocks.preview: - Oral feeding is more physiologic and stimulates enteric hormones, salivary gland, gastric and panc

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Factors to Consider
blocks.preview: - Oral feeding may not be achievable as clinical condition, mechanical ventilation or intestinal dys

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Factors to Consider
blocks.preview: - Jejunal feeding usually is limited to patients with gastric dysmotility, severe gastroesophageal r

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Factors to Consider - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - Continuous infusion of enteral nutrition increases mucosal contact and may improve absorption per

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Factors to Consider - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - Continuous feeding eliminates fasting periods and affects motility of the intestine

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Factors to Consider - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - Bolus feeding mimics normal feeding patterns and stimulates the release of gastrointestinal hormon

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Factors to Consider - Cont'd
blocks.preview: - Continuous feeding may improve tolerance when bolus feeds are not tolerated

Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Feeding should transition to solid food when child is developmentally ready

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Aim for nutrient dense, calorie dense foods

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Balance the meal plan; encourage foods from each food group

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Tailor meal plans to the individual

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Encourage 5 - 6 small meals or snacks a day

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Smaller volumes of food at once may allow enhanced absorption by decreasing the nutrient load per

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Encourage high protein sources, generous complex carbohydrate intake

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Chew foods well

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - If the colon is in continuity

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Limit fat in the diet (<30\%)

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Malabsorbed fat binds to calcium instead of oxalate in the gut lumen which may lead to kidney ston

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome
blocks.preview: - Encourage soluble fiber

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: General Diet Guidelines in Short Bowel Syndrome

blocks.preview: - Encourage drinking small amounts of fluid with meals and throughout the day
- Avoid excessive enteral fluid intake at once, especially in those with an ostomy, as this may lead
- Additional sodium is often needed, especially in patients without a colon
- Oral rehydration solution (ORS) helps to replace sodium losses
- Water absorption in the small intestine is dependent on sodiumglucose co-transport
- Commercial and homemade ORS may help hydration

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Many patients with intestinal failure will require vitamin and mineral supplementation

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Influenced by the length of remaining bowel, absorptive ability, transit time and dietary intake

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Water soluble forms of fat-soluble vitamins (DEKAs) may be needed

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Micronutrient levels are to be monitored closely and supplemented as needed

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Fat soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K)

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Vitamin B12

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Calcium, magnesium

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Zinc, iron, copper and selenium

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals
blocks.preview: - Recommend monitoring every 3 - 6 months

blocks.section: Transition to Enteral Feeds: Vitamins and Minerals

blocks.preview: - Increased survival in children with IF has resulted in a need for continued healthcare for childre
- Care of children on PN is complex and the risk of complications is high
- 'Healthcare transition' is an active process that addresses medical, psychosocial and education ne
- Patients must learn daily tasks including CVC care, administering PN and tube feedings, medication

blocks.section: Adult Transition in Long-Term PN: Barriers
Adult Transition in Long-Term PN: Barriers
blocks.preview: - Many barriers to successful transition exist in this setting of a complex chronic illness requirin

blocks.section: Adult Transition in Long-Term PN: Barriers
blocks.preview: - The most common barrier is difficulty leaving the pediatric team with which they have had a long-s

blocks.section: Adult Transition in Long-Term PN: Barriers
blocks.preview: - There is a lack of adult clinicians and multidisciplinary teams caring for intestinal failure

blocks.section: Adult Transition in Long-Term PN: Barriers
blocks.preview: - Patients may have delayed neurodevelopment, health literacy, medical complexity and limited knowle

blocks.section: Adult Transition in Long-Term PN: Barriers

blocks.preview: - A structured program with a multidisciplinary approach is crucial for successful transition
- Education for adolescents about their medical care includes:
- Understanding their specific anatomy
- Medical device use and care (CVC, ostomy, feeding tubes)
- Nutrition and medications
- Accessing medical care
- Understanding complications and when to seek care
- This period of transition should focus on a therapeutic relationship and nurturing to becoming ind
- The transition process should start in early adolescence with the patient participating actively i
- Adolescents progress to take on a manager role of healthcare tasks as parents supervise
- Patients should demonstrate the ability to independently manage all aspects of their health before

A 3-month-old baby born with intestinal atresia, underwent bowel resection her first week of life. S
You meet with her parents to discuss her care. The parents ask when they will be able to take their
A) Parenteral nutrition should be cycled
B) The child should have a tunneled venous catheter placed
C) When the child is weaned off parenteral nutrition
D) When two caregivers are trained in central line care and able to administer PN at home

The parent of a 5-year-old patient with a history intestinal failure due to short bowel syndrome rea
A. Immediately have the parent bring the child to the emergency room for evaluation
B. Inquire how many hours of PN the child typically receives
C. Ask the parent to reposition the patient and try to flush the line again
D. Instruct the parent to call back in the morning to troubleshoot the issue

A 3-year-old boy has received parenteral nutrition since birth due to a history of volvulus. He curr
All of the following are true regarding the transition off parenteral nutrition except,
A. Oral rehydration solutions are beneficial in weaning off parenteral nutrition
B. Continuous tube feeding is necessary to stop parenteral nutrition
C. They should encourage small meals and frequent snacks throughout the day.
D. He will likely need more enteral calories as compared to parenteral calories to maintain his grow
